did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Constance M. Green papers, undated
did.abstract: Collection primarily contains notes and early drafts of Constance Green's writings, and also includes pamphlets, bibliographies, and classroom materials in the area of urban and negro studies.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: The George Washington University, The Gelman Library, Special Collections Research Center

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Constance M. Green Papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Constance McLaughlin Green (1897-1975) was an accomplished historian and author of many scholarly books about urban history in the United States. Green was director of the Washington History Project at American University and an active member of the Committee of 100 on the Federal City. She won the 1963 Pulitzer Prize in history for the first volume of her study of Washington, D.C., "Washington: Village and Capital, 1800-1878."

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection primarily contains notes and early drafts of Green's writings, and also includes pamphlets, bibliographies, and classroom materials in the area of urban and negro studies.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized in five series: Notes to "The Secret City," Pamphlets and bibliographies on urban and negro studies, Class materials and student essays from the course "Negro Life in American Cities since 1860," Typescripts of later writings including "The Church on Lafayette Square," and Early drafts of "Washington, Capital City, 1879-1950."

did.unittitle: Class materials and student essays from the course "Negro Life in American Cities since 1860", 1969

scopecontent.p: This series contains notes, bibliographical material, and student essays from the class "Negro Life in American Cities Since 1860," taught by Constance Green at the George Washington University in the summer of 1969.

did.unittitle: "Negro Life in American Cities Since 1860", undated
"The Urban Negro American In The 20th Century" and class discussion notes., undated

note.p: A survey of sources. Bibliographical material on diverse topics within the subject. Organization and comments of unknown authorship.

did.unittitle: Students Essays. 14, including grades given., undated
Typescripts of later writings including "The Church on Lafayette Square", undated

scopecontent.p: This series contains typescripts of an essay titled "Urbanization, Technology, and the Historian" and a book titled "The Church on Lafayette Square: A History of St. John's Church, Washington, D.C.," both by Constance Green.

did.unittitle: Typescripts of Late Writings, undated
"Urbanization, Technology anf The Historian" typescript, undated

note.p: This paper focusus on the historian's role in evaluating and researching the process of city-building,and its connection with the growth of technology. She discusses the state of research in the field of urban evolution as it was in the 1960's, and the approaches of several historians. Valuable insight into the needs of further study is given, along with extensive notes and bibliographical material.

did.unittitle: Typescript, The Church on Lafayette Square: A History of St.John's Church, Wash.,D.C., undated

note.p: incomplete typescript by Constance McLaughlin Green.
